title: Ticket #7284: Job route order doesn't reflect configuration
description:
Our friends at CIEMAT/PIC reported on htcondor-users that the job route ordering does not reflect what they've added to the configuration, which causes confusion with how jobs are routed. For example, the following configuration (note the lack of requirements): 

8.8 configuration fragment
JOB_ROUTER_ENTRIES @=jre
[
  TargetUniverse = 5;
  name = "Local_Condor";
]
[
  TargetUniverse = 5;
  name = "Local_Condor2";
]
[
  TargetUniverse = 5;
  name = "Local_Condor3";
]
@jre

Results in the following ordering that is reflected in the job router log: 

Route Name             Submitted/Max        Idle/Max     Throttle Recent: Started Succeeded Failed
Local_Condor2                  0/  10000       0/   2000     none               0         0      0
Local_Condor                   0/  10000       0/   2000     none               0         0      0
Local_Condor3                  0/  10000       0/   2000     none               0         0      0

And so any submitted jobs actually only match to the Local_Condor2 route when we would expect them to route to Local_Condor from our configuration.

Unfortunately, the actual situation is more complicated. There is not a single declaration order that we can use. The job router reads 3 knobs: JOB_ROUTER_ENTRIES, JOB_ROUTER_ENTRIES_FILE, and JOB_ROUTER_ENTRIES_CMD and uses the set of all routes declared there after eliminating duplicates (by name, case sensitively). The case-sensitive comparison of names is a bug, it should be case insensitive. Routes are stored in a hashtable, and then applied in hashtable order, which is the source of the problem.

If we fix the case-sensitivity bug, that will change the hashtable order; which will potentially break configurations that happen to work now because hashtable order is working for them.

So we plan to fix this problem by adding a knob JOB_ROUTE_NAMES. This will default to empty. If it is empty, then routes will be compared in hashtable order using the current case-sensitive hash. If it is not empty, then only routes listed in this knob will be used, and they will be compared in the order specified in the knob. Names specified in this knob will be treated as case-*IN*sensitive.

in 8.8 We will also change the job router to compare case-*IN*sensitively when eliminating routes with the same name, since this is necessary to make the new knob work correctly.

In the 8.9 series, we will add a Schedd style method of declaring routes, where each route will be specified by a knob whose name ends with the route name, something like this 

8.9 job router configuration fragment
JOB_ROUTER_ROUTE_NAMES = Local_Condor2, Local_Condor
JOB_ROUTER_ROUTE_Local_Condor @=end
[
  TargetUniverse = 5;
  name = "Local_Condor";
]
@end
JOB_ROUTER_ROUTE_Local_Condor2 @=end
[
  TargetUniverse = 5;
  name = "Local_Condor2";
]
@end

Additionally, in 8.9 we will also support the native transform syntax as an alternative to job router syntax for specifying routes. so this will also work 

8.9 job router configuration fragment
JOB_ROUTER_ROUTE_NAMES = Local_Condor Local_Condor2
JOB_ROUTER_ROUTE_Local_Condor @=end
  NAME Local_Condor
  Universe Vanilla
  SET Requirements ($(MY.Requirements)) && NeedMorePylons
@end
JOB_ROUTER_ROUTE_LocalCondor2 @=end
  Name Local_Condor2
  TargetUniverse 5
  Set routedTo "Local2"
@end

2019-Nov-08 15:54:44 by blin:
I tested the EL7 RPMs from this build here: http://submit-3.batlab.org/results/run-details.php?runid=488423, and things look good to me.

  • JOB_ROUTE_NAMES appears to be respected to first order
  • Without setting JOB_ROUTE_NAMES, the route order appears to be the same hash table order as the previous version
  • condor_job_router_info -config now shows the route order without routes that have been excluded by leaving them out of JOB_ROUTE_NAMES
